messages: 28a6d36d2fd2e2e987a704be0c3f7b0e (11:35): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: so is Apple/Samsung/whatever willing to put the extra hardware to cater to European countries that got enchanted by the smart card lobby?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:36): but if there is money to be made from it in selling more devices, I'd think so

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:38): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: back when Finland tried this, we got a couple of crappy computers from Fujitsu with built-in support. that was it. Fortunately, the whole thing flopped.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:39): yeah, I wonder how the current trend will play out in the long run
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:42): also, I don't really want any special interest to replay the digital tv coup, where they made a lot of people replace hardware just because
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:42): yeah, that would be bad
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:42): but in this case, people seem to like the convenience
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:42): hahahahah
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:42): this smart card stuff has nothing to do with user convenience
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:43): it's all about vendors convincing governments that there's a problem that needs solving
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:43): when that same problem has never been equally solved pre-Internet and the sky hasn't fallen
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:44): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: sorry if "hahahahah" was rude.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:44): but this is so far removed from the needs of the *users*
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:44): I guess I don't really know what the difference is between smart cards and the contactless cards and e-wallet features on mobile phones we have in Japan
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:44): no problem man :)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:45): you should laugh more often!
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:45): I'm glad to provide some mirth
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:46): anyway, the use case I had in mind is just the use case of being able to pay for stuff easily without needing to carry cash
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:47): I take it that in Europe, the use case that the vendors are trying to sell governments on is just electronic identification
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:47): what goverments in Europe try to do is to make login to government Web sites more "secure" than login to Google or Paypal
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:48): and more secure than login to banks
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:49): Hmm, the situation we have is that login to government websites is pretty much equivalent to login to banks
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:49): because, you know, no one has never just phoned a government office and stated their name and id number
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:49): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: in Finland, login to goverment sites is now outsourced to banks, because the smart card thing sucked so badly
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:49): Right, taht is mostly the case here
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:50): There are various identity providers and banks are one of them
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:50): Banks in turn are typically protected by some kind of hardware challenge/response system
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:51): this situation is *much* better than smart cards, because because typing some numbers from a laminated piece of paper is browser, OS and device-neutral
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:51): (not sure if I am using the right technical terms here)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:51): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: over here, the "hardware" that the user possesses is a piece of paper with some plastic coating
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:51): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: works great except with gullible people and phishing
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:51): (but the system is device neutral to the extent that the bank website works on different devices/browsers)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:52): (and one option for government login requires java. There is also a mobile phone based alternative)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:52): but then, smart cards are also vulnerable to gullible users
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:53): in fact, using smart cards requires more leaps of faith from the user

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:54): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Here you get some hardware for which you have a PIN. The bank site presents a number, you enter that number into the device and then enter the corresponding number into the bank website.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:55): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I guess that protects gullible people from blatant phishing better than what we have
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:55): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: but probably doesn't help people who are excessively gullible
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:55): compared to the piece of paper that is
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:56): with the piece of paper, the bank is supposed to ask for one printed number at a time
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:57): but since the user has all the numbers available, a particularly audacious phisher can ask the user to type *all* of them at once
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:57): of course, the user has to be super-gullible to fall for that one
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:57): I don't know if people who fall for that one can be helped in terms of computer security
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:06): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I'm wondering how the validator deals with "xmlns:" in text/html
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:07): I see the parser does not expose "xmlns:*" as attributes to the rest of the SAX pipeline
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:07): as far as I can see
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:08): and doesn't support the sax namespace-prefixes feature
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:09): so I'm wondering how the validator service is able to see report xmlnis:* attributes
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:11): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: IIRC, the parser reports them, then doesn't show them to the pipeline
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:12): ah, OK
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:13): hmm, but jing sees them
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:13): then I misremember
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:14): well, I mean I can see that the error message seems to be a kind that jing emits
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:14): "Attribute xmlns:foo not allowed here"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:15): that is emitted by the parser
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:15): my bad
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:16): that's in the treebuilder code
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:16): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: yes. private void checkAttributes(HtmlAttributes attributes, @NsUri String ns)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:16): yep yep
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:16): OK, that is good news
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:16): or good for me to get confirmation of that
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:16): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: fun with RDFa, eh?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:16): you guessed it man
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:17): xmlns is deprecated in RDFa 1.1
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:17): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I suggest not supporting deprecated parts

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:17): however, the spec currently says, "Conformance checkers must accept attribute names that have a case insensitive prefix matching "xmlns:" as conforming. Conformance checkers should generate warnings noting that the use of xmlns: is deprecated."
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:17): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:17): agreed
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:20): if anything that part of the spec should be changed to say, "Conformance checkers may report xmlns attributes as errors"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:20): anyway, it's also not clear whether xmlns is an error in RDFa Lite or not
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:20): not clear to me anyway
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:29): oh, looks like gecko implementation of Network Status API just landed
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:29): https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=677166
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (12:31): And some SMS stuff too
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:31): navigator.mozConnection.bandwidth
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:31): SMS stuff?
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (12:35): https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=674725
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:39): wishes this stuff wasn't moz-prefixed
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:40): that SMS landing sure had lots of changesets
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (12:40): wishes this stuff was being specced
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (12:40): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, even better, it didn't build
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:41): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: IIRC, there's a draft for the network status API
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:41): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: is there not a spec for SMS?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:42): the implementation is different from network status API draft
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:42): for good reasons
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:42): hopefully the spec will get revised
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (12:42): AIUI, the plan is to try to establish a significant legacy through b2g, and then spec our implementation
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (12:52): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: is wikimo not a spec but draft in some random website which has html or html5 in the domain name is a draft?
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (12:52): though, perhaps you did mean that wikimo draft is a draft spec
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (12:59): No, what I meant is that wikimo is owned by one vendor, while html5.org or whatwg.org isn't
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:04): html5.org and whatwg.org are both owned by employees of vendors
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (13:05): But wikimo is a Mozilla asset, and whatwg.org isn't a Google asset
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:21): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: sent you some patch review requests
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:23): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I'll take a look
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:23): thanks
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:23): sorry it's all pretty boring stuff
